ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You learn about ethics.
I improved my typing speed significantly. I also learned a lot about approaches taken to examine different situations.
I learned how to act during ethical dilemmas in a professional setting

I learned that being a successful professional and being ethical are not mutually exclusive. I learned about the different ways various businesses in various fields have to think about and go about functioning ethically. I particularly liked that the media we consumed varied greatly-- from tv shows, to movies, to articles-- and were relevant to our present situation.

A great class to introduce Kantian ethics, Utilitarianism, virtue ethics and John Rawls justice principles. If you plan on being a CEO then I highly recommend this class it provides very applicable readings to leading a company.

This course developed many ethical skills and perspectives that I feel will be useful for future work life! We got to address and discuss issues that allowed me to learn both how to better argue a position and how to understand the nuance of a given ethical dilemma.

A very basic, surface-level understanding of philosophical concepts, which likely would have been better taught in a philosophy department class. The ethical case studies in the class were very interesting though, and the balance between lecture and podcast or film worked well (although the case studies were not always related to the lecture materials, which sometimes felt disjointed.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very interesting material, but the homework assignments were unnecessary.

The course largely is just 30 case studies you write and a final paper, which means the in class materials are not as relevant compared to other classes.; might be a positive or negative depending on what you are looking for

This class was just really....bad. I have no idea if it was because of zoom or what, but my experience was horrible. Professor Carreras is absolutely the sweetest lady alive but it was an unorganized class where I really had no idea what was going on.

Strengths- Dr. Carreras was very kind and helpful. She made the class worth attending. Her lectures were fun too given that she showed different movies and shows to supplement her material. 

Weakness- The case studies took a long time to complete (2-3, 5 page papers per week) and they never were discussed in class. They were graded fairly, but they felt like busy work.
A nice fun course that provides some interesting thought experiments
Greater student participation with the questions posed would have strengthened students' ability to hear various perspectives on ethical dilemas.
This course is very accessible in terms of how gradually the content is introduced. The weekly assignments are pretty light roughly ~2-3 hours a week. All around great class.

The classes are engaging, with great discussions and interesting, topical issues. The main weakness was the volume of case studies we did outside of class, though this was mainly an issue due to the compressed schedule of this semester.

While Professor Carreras is a lovely, kind-hearted person, I do not believe this course should be taught again. Each class consisted of Professor Carreras simply reading text off her presentation slides, and while there was some class discussion, the classes felt like pre-recorded lectures. When the class ended, Professor Carreras would stop abruptly in the middle of the presentation and would not finish the topic in any of the subsequent classes. The homework assignments were entirely unrelated to the class materials and were comparable to middle school homework assignments, mainly asking us to write up what was discussed in each paragraph of a reading. While the case studies presented in class were interesting, they would have been much more pertinent if they had been connected to the class materials and homework assignments, which many were not.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a lot of busy work and lecture and the course packet assignments didn't really match up at all.
Dr. Carreras did an excellent job to keep her students engaged.
The virtual lectures were good and the process of turning in writing assignments on canvas worked well.

Prof. Carreras was very understanding and flexible. The break out rooms were a little lacking in terms of actual discussion because only a few people turned their cameras on and even less actually participated. The senior demographic makes the class not too live and harms the constructive conversations which could be had.
Class discussions and breakout rooms helped to facilitate my learning. The class really felt like it was in-person, despite being digital!

A lot more engagement from the professor beyond reading text from the slides is needed for a virtual teaching format. Break-out rooms were very unsuccessful, with most students just doing their homework assignments while in break-out rooms.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want a low workload class about ethics that is largely self-driven go for it.

Absolutely not. I took this as a gut for a social science credit and I wish I just decided to take a more engaging but harder course. I learned absolutely nothing and will not retain anything. Ill probably consider this as one of the worst classes I've ever taken. Prof. Carreras is sweet though, so it's nothing on her just the class itself.
Yes. It is a lot of work, but it is definitely worth it. The professor and excellent and really works to create a relationship with her students.
If youre looking for an interesting low stakes class then yes
Yes! Its an accessible approach to ethics and philosophy!
Yes, Professor Carreras is an amazing teacher.
The course was more insightful than I anticipated. I would recommend to anyone who is interested in a social science credit that is informative and is of medium difficulty.

I would highly recommend any class taught by prof. Mercedes. All her subjects are very interesing and applicable to STEM students. Professional ethics teaches students how to approach work place dilemmas such as bribery, sexual misconduct, and other ethical/ moral problems.
Take this course!! The professor is amazing and the topics are quite interesting, useful, and thought-provoking. It is a lot of fun!
Absolutely not - this class is not worth your time and efforts, and you will not gain much from an academic standpoint.

comments: Also recorded the lectures.
